> First, the Strategy Pattern buys you some flexibility at the cost of
> some added complexity.  You could read the principle of YAGNI as
> saying don't pay for the flexibility until you know you need it.  If I
> don't have any real reason to believe that I'm likely to swap in a new
> algorithm later, then moving the algorithm into its own class could be
> seen as overkill.  (There are still, however, plenty of reasons to
> encapsulate it in its own method, like readability and coherence.)

Remember: YAGNI means you shouldn't invest in *functionality* you just don't
need for now; it shouldn't be used for excuses to not try to get the best
(most readable/maintainable) design for the funtionality you just need.

> Moving it into its own class does buy you something in simplifying the
> testing, though, so is that (up-front, immediate) benefit sufficient
> to justify the cost of the pattern?

As you pointed out above, there may be other benefits. Test-first
programming is not only a testing strategy, but also (if not mainly) a
design strategy. If you find something hard to test, it *may* be an
indicator that the design needs to be improved.

ciao, Ilja
